<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_dma_map:
```c
int metal_dma_map(struct metal_device *dev,
		  uint32_t dir,
		  struct metal_sg *sg_in,
		  int nents_in,
		  struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	int nents_out;

	if (!dev || !sg_in || !sg_out)
		return -EINVAL;
	if (!dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_map)
		return -ENODEV;

	/* memory barrier */
	if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_R)
		/* If it is device read, apply memory write fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_release);
	else
		/* If it is device write or r/w, apply memory r/w fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_acq_rel);
	nents_out = dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_map(dev->bus,
			dev, dir, sg_in, nents_in, sg_out);
	return nents_out;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (!dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_map)
		return -ENODEV;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No unreachable code is present. The if-statement is reachable: when dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_map is NULL the function returns -ENODEV; when it is non-NULL execution continues and the later call is reachable. (Note: there is a potential null-pointer dereference risk if dev->bus or dev->bus->ops is NULL, but that is a safety/undefined-behavior issue, not an instance of unreachable code under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.)
